title-group.article-title: Spatiotemporal Analysis of Relative Convergence of EEGs Reveals Differences Between Brain Dynamics of Depressive Women and Men

article-meta.aff: 2Departments of Biomedical Engineering, Biomedical Informatics, Civil and Environmental Engineering and Geodetic Science, Electrical and Computer Engineering, Neurological Surgery, and Neuroscience, The Ohio State University, Columbus, OH, USA
3Department of Neurology, The Ohio State University, Columbus, OH, USA

author-notes.corresp: Hojjat Adeli, Departments of Biomedical Engineering, Biomedical Informatics, Civil and Environmental Engineering and Geodetic Science, Electrical and Computer Engineering, Neurological Surgery, and Neuroscience, The Ohio State University, 470 Hitchcock Hall, 2070 Neil Avenue, Columbus, OH 43210, USA. Email: adeli.1@osu.edu

abstract.p: A new nonlinear technique for analysis of brain dynamics called spatiotemporal analysis of relative convergence (STARC) of electroencephalograms (EEGs) is introduced, based on the relative convergence of EEGs of different loci. This technique shows how many times EEGs of each loci pair converge together, which in turn is used as an indicator to determine the different neuronal regions involved in performing the same task. A higher STARC value indicates that more regions are recruited to perform the same task. The STARC methodology was used to reveal sex difference pathophysiology and brain dynamics, using EEG data from 11 male and 11 female adults with major depressive disorder (MDD). The results show significant differences in relative convergences of EEGs of intraleft temporal and frontoleft temporal lobes at δ band, between male and female patients.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p:
MDD is among the most common affective disorders, with a lifetime prevalence of 17% to 21%. 1,2 The main symptoms are persistent feeling of sadness (or emptiness), fatigue, loss of interest in enjoying activities, diminished ability of thinking or concentration, and sleep disturbances. 3
–6 Although the relation of depression to functional impairments in cognitive domains is known, 7 the underlying neural circuitry and pathophysiology of depression is not yet completely understood. 8,9 Moreover, MDD is 2 times more prevalent in women than in men, 10 which may be associated with sex differences of MDD pathophysiology, rather than only social conditions.

There are many studies in the literature on pathophysiology of MDD without considering gender as an affective factor. Imaging-based studies have shown some minor abnormalities in the brains of patients with MDDs, which consist of structural and volumetric changes in hippocampus 11
–14 and changes in white matter. 13,15,16 Brain signal-based studies have reported mainly frontal EEG asymmetry at α subband in patients with MDD. 17
–20 Also, some studies, all imaging based, have investigated MDD limited to only one gender. Kim et al found decreased volume of gray matter in caudate nucleus of women with depression. 21 Chen et al reported reduced hippocampal volume in daughters of mothers with a history of depression (high-risk girls), compared with low-risk girls. 22

Any finding of sex differences in pathophysiology and brain dynamics in patients with MDD can lead to better understanding of their brain mechanisms. Until now, however, only a few studies reported significant differences in brain pathophysiology and disrupted brain dynamics between men and women with depression, based on EEGs and imaging techniques. Using imaging (magnetic resonance imaging and single-photon emission computed tomography) techniques, Staley et al 10 examined sex differences in the serotonergic function that underlies many of the cardinal symptoms in MDD. They found lower availability of diencephalon 5-HT transporter in an age-dependent manner in women with depression, which was not observed in men with depression. However, there are no reported sex differences when EEG was used in the awake condition. It has been reported that men and women with MDD have different slow-wave activities and δ wave counts during non-rapid eye movement sleep. 23
–26 The authors conjecture that the main reason for not revealing any sex differences in EEG-based studies of awake patients may be due to the use of linear methods such as coherence 27 –29 and power spectrum analysis, which are not suitable for discovering the dynamics of a highly complex and nonlinear system, such as in the brain. 30

In this article, the authors introduce a new nonlinear technique called STARC of EEGs for analysis of brain dynamics, based on relative convergence of EEGs of different loci. The STARC analysis quantifies recurrence of the EEGs in terms of states being close together. Firing of 2 neuronal regions, roughly in the same phase and with the same amplitude shows how much the neuronal regions tend to behave in the same manner. This technique shows how many times EEGs of each loci pair converge together, which in turn is used as an indicator to determine the different neuronal regions involved in performing the same task. A higher STARC value indicates that more regions are recruited to perform the same task, or shows a high repetition of neuronal region conditions, which is expected in depression due to rumination, an episode of depression when the patient repeats some meaningless thoughts unwillingly. Rumination is defined as long chains of repetitive and recyclic self-focused negative thinking. 31 The proposed STARC method is used to reveal sex difference pathophysiology and brain dynamics in MDD. The analysis is performed within the innovative wavelet-chaos methodology advanced by Adeli et al, 32 with the goal of finding the dynamic differences between women and men with depression, not only in full-band EEG but also in subband EEGs.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: According to wavelet-chaos methodology, 32 first, using a wavelet filter bank, EEGs of women and men with depression are decomposed into 5 EEG subbands: γ (30-70 Hz), β (15-30 Hz), α (8-12 Hz), θ (4-8 Hz), and δ(1-4 Hz; for detailed information refer to ref 33 ). The next step is computation of the convergence of loci pair EEGs using STARC in subbands as well as the full-band EEG. Then, the difference in convergence of dynamics of the pair region EEGs is assessed between the 2 groups, men and women with MDD, using the analysis of variation (ANOVA) statistical test. Finally, in order to show the ability of the proposed method for revealing sex difference in MDD pathophysiology, the selected STARC features in the subbands and full-band EEGs, those that show the most meaningful differences between the 2 groups, are used as input to a recently developed classifier called enhanced probabilistic neural network (EPNN), 34 an enhanced version of probabilistic neural network (PNN), 2,35 –37 to discriminate the EEGs of the male and female patients with MDD.

sec.title: The STARC of EEGs
sec.p:

sec.title: Topography and Regional STARC
sec.p: Data for each patient consist of 19 signals according to 10-20 international standard protocols. The topography used in this research consists of 6 regions illustrated in Figure 2: frontal (Fp1, Fp2, F3, F4, and Fz), left lateral (F7, T3, and T5), right lateral (F8, T4, and T6), central (C3, C4, and Cz), parietal (P3, P4, and Pz), and occipital (O1 and O2). The regional relative convergence of dynamics of 2 neuronal regions is computed through averaging the relative convergence values between all electrode pairs in those regions (one electrode in one region and one in the other region). All regional relative convergence values are computed in the full-band EEG and each EEG subband.

caption.p: Illustration of 10-20 electrode loci and the topography used in this research, which consisted of 6 regions: frontal (Fp1, Fp2, F3, F4, and Fz), left lateral (F7, T3, and T5), right lateral (F8, T4, and T6), central (C3, C4, and Cz), parietal (P3, P4, and Pz), and occipital (O1 and O2).

sec.title: Statistical Analysis and Classification
sec.p: One-way ANOVA is used to evaluate the ability of the computed regional relative convergence values, in EEG full-band and subbands, to discriminate the male and female groups with depression. In this study, the threshold P value of the significant ability to discriminate is .001. Also, in the same manner, 1-way ANOVA is used to find out whether gender differences exist in the healthy participants. This additional analysis is performed in order to examine the ability of STARC methodology to distinguish the gender differences specific to MDD. To find out whether differences in the STARC features between genders in the MDD group are a result of different deficit types and psychopathology in patients with MDD, or it is simply a gender difference irrespective of the gender-specific effects of the disorder.

The correlation between severity scores of depression in the participants with MDD and the STARC values is evaluated using Pearson coefficient of correlation. Next, in order to show the ability of the proposed nonlinear analysis to reveal the gender differences of MDD, discriminative regional relative convergence values are selected for classification of EEG data into male and female groups, using the EPNN. 34 Inputs of EPNN are the features discovered by 1-way ANOVA in the previous step. The EPNN consists of an input layer with number of nodes equal to the number of selected features, a pattern layer that computes the likelihood of the input data to each training data, using 2 local and global Bayesian rules, a summation layer that computes the likelihood of the input data to each class (in this work, autistic and healthy), and an output layer with 1 node, which assigns the input data to the class with maximum likelihood. The number of nodes in the pattern layer is equal to the number of training data, and the number of nodes in the summation layer is the same as the number of classes.

To evaluate effectiveness of the proposed method to discriminate female and male MDDs, 3 other conventional methods of EEG characteristics were computed in the full-band EEG and EEG subbands: power, cross-correlation, and Hilbert phase synchronization (see 38 for definitions). ANOVA was used to quantify the ability of these characteristics to discriminate female and male MDDs.

sec.title: Data Acquisition
sec.p: The data were recorded at Atieh Comprehensive Center for Psych and Nerve Disorders, Tehran, Iran. They are resting eyes-closed EEG data of 22 non-medicated adults with MDD, 11 men (20 - 28 years old: 24 ± 2.3) and 11 women (20 - 28 years old: 22 ± 1.7), as well as resting eyes-closed EEG data of 20 healthy adults, 10 men (22 - 29 years old: 25 ± 2.7) and 10 women (20 - 27 years old: 23 ± 2.1). The healthy participants had no history of neurological and neuropsychiatric disorders. All patients were diagnosed by Diagnastic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (Fourth Edition) criteria, and their severity of depression was scored by Beck depression inventory (ranging from 0 to 63). 39 The scores of all patients with MDD were more than 30, the cutoff for severe depression. Female patients scored 41 ± 4.7, and the male patients scored 38 ± 5.9. All participants gave written informed consent before beginning the study. The individuals were asked to sit calmly on a comfortable chair (in a quiet room), without moving, blinking, or swallowing saliva. EEGs were recorded using a 19-channel electocap according to the 10-20 standard protocol (see Figure 2), referenced by linked ears, and grounded by Fpz, with a sampling rate of 256 Hz, an impedance of <10 kΩ, and 16 digits. EEG recording lasted 3 minutes (3 × 60 × 256 = 46, 080 time samples). An interval of 15,360 points of data from each EEG was selected free of eye blinking or other artifacts. Figure 3 shows samples of 1-second EEGs recorded from Fz (Figure 2) for a female patient (A), a male patient (B), a healthy female (C), and a healthy male (D).

caption.p: One-second sample of electroencephalograms (EEGs) recorded from Fz of (A) a female with major depressive disorder (MDD), (B) a male with MDD, (C) a healthy female, and (D) a healthy male.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Regional STARC analysis was accomplished within the wavelet-chaos methodology of Adeli et al. 32 Regional relative convergence values among the 6 topographical regions defined in Figure 2 were computed for full-band EEG and 5 subbands. In the first statistical analysis for discrimination of genders in the MDD group, the discriminative values (P value < .001) were found only in δ subband and in intraleft temporal and frontoleft temporal lobes. Figure 4 demonstrates discriminative STARC values of female and male MDDs in δ subband in intraleft temporal (x axis) and frontoleft temporal (y axis) lobes. The values for female and male patients with MDD are depicted by squares and circles, respectively. These 2 discriminative regional relative convergence values (relative for the intraregion means convergence of dynamics of loci in the same region relative to each other) were used as input for the EPNN classifier (with 2 input nodes) to classify the EEG data into male and female groups with depression. The classification was performed randomly 100 times, using 73% (16 data) of the data for training and 27% (6 data) for testing. This method is called repeated random subsampling (RRS) validation. In addition, leave one out (LOO) was used as another cross-validation method 40 to validate the classification accuracy. Accuracies of 91.1% (with variation of 2.4%) and 95.8% were obtained by the RRS and LOO validations, respectively, for distinguishing the male and female groups, based on the STARC approach. There was no meaningful correlation between the severity scores of depression and STARC values. Also, based on Pearson coefficient of correlation, STARC analysis did not show any difference between healthy males and females (P value >.064).

caption.p: Demonstration of the discriminative spatiotemporal analysis of relative convergence (STARC) values (P value < .001) in δ subband in intraleft temporal (x axis) and frontoleft temporal (y axis) lobes. The values of female and male patients with MDD are depicted by squares and circles, respectively.

sec.p: A second ANOVA was performed to find the probable differences between the genders in the normal/healthy group. Likewise, regional relative convergence values among the 6 topographical regions were computed for full-band EEG and 5 subbands, and ANOVA was applied. Results showed no difference in the STARC values, in any frequency bands, between the healthy male and female groups.

Power, cross-correlation, and Hilbert phase synchronization were computed in the full-band EEG and subbands in both male and female MMD groups. ANOVA did not show any statistically meaningful differences in powers in the regions, and did not show any cross-correlations within and between the regions (P values > .05). Hilbert phase synchronization showed significance between-group differences in δ in intraleft temporal region (P value = .012), but the P value was not comparable to those obtained by STARC (P value < .001).

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Any difference in the structure and function of brain in male and female patients with MDD can help researchers understand the genetic–psychological roots of MDD, which in turn can lead to the development of more efficacious gender-specific treatments. Brain dynamics can be recognized through nonlinear analysis of EEG. 41,43 However, there is no reliable technique based on EEG for revealing gender differences in the brain dynamics of the population with MDD. In this article, in order to reveal the gender differences in the pathophysiology and brain dynamics of patients with MDD, authors proposed the STARC approach as a novel method, based on the relative convergence of EEGs of brain loci. STARC indicates how much different neuronal areas tend to fire in the same manner. Higher repetition of conditions in the neuronal areas involved leads to a higher value of the relative convergence of the EEGs.

STARC methodology was tested using EEG data of 22 non-medicated pateints adults with MDD and 20 healthy adults. The results show significant differences in relative convergences of EEGs of intraleft temporal and frontoleft temporal lobes at δ band between the male and female patients. Interestingly, frontal lobe and temporal lobe pathology has been noted in major depression, in previous studies. 44 Statistical analysis did not show any gender differences between STARC values of healthy participants.

The same STARC analysis was applied to EEGs of 10 male and 10 female healthy adults. The ANOVA test showed no difference between healthy male and female patients, thus confirming the hypothesis of this research that the differences in the STARC values between male and female patients with MDD imply the gender differences in the MDD pathophysiology.

The relative convergence of EEGs of brain areas can be construed as representation of trends of the related neuronal areas to fire synchronously. In this view, the reduced frontotemporal convergence of EEGs in men with depression compared to women with depression, discovered through STARC, represents reduced frontotemporal connectivity in men with depression compared to women with depression. The reduced frontotemporal connectivity in males with depression may be associated with reduction in gray matter density. 45

Previously, some reports showed a significant difference in gray matter between healthy males and females. 46 –48 Women have a higher tendency then men for rumination in a depressive mood. 31,49 Some studies showed that during the first episode of depression, the hippocampal volume was decreased in men with depression, while it was enlarged in women with depression, concurrent with a longer first episode of depression in men compared to women. 50,51 Future investigation of correlations between STARC value and gray matter density, rumination severity, duration of first episode of depression, and hippocampal volume in patients with depression, can find possible relations between the psychophysiological factors and the STARC methodology.

fn.p: Full-color figures are available online at http://eeg.sagepub.com
